body: @kovetskiy probably, but that feels like part of #2. This feature would not consider line length at all.

> This rule could be made stronger in the future, such as enforcing parameters to all be on separate lines

I'm actually interested in writing such a lint-check for our own organization.  It would have the semantics that if a function's "first line" (receiver + name + parameter list + return) does not fit on one line, it requires it to be broken it up so that each parameter is on own line, and possibly each return value (and possibly the receiver) as well.  It would require, as input, a line-length limit.

Would there be interest in incorporating this into gfumpt (presumably opt-in) if I wrote it?  If so I might do it that way, rather than as a separate linter.

(I would write this error to be auto-fixable, if that's possible in gofumpt -- I don't know enough about the tool yet to say.  Our org would be using this as part of golangci-lint, which recently brought in gofumpt support, which is what led me here.)
(Ah, I see now this is discussed at length in #2, so maybe it's premature to consider it for gofumpt at this time.)

@csilvers breaking up long lines would be #2, yes. There is a WIP PR if you want to give it a try.

The rule here (and the potential follow-up you linked) would be based purely on consistency with newlines, not on line length limits. That being said, if we implement a rule like "if any parameter is in a separate line, all parameters are on separate lines", then #2 splitting the parameter list due to the line length limit could then cascade into that rule.

issue.title: force multiline function signatures to separate the body
